Output:

For zinc (Zn), the Random Forest (RF) model showed the best prediction performance with significant R2 values of 0.74 (p < 0.01) during training and 0.7 (p < 0.01) during testing. This indicates a strong correlation between the predicted and actual concentrations of zinc in the stream sediments.

instruction: How do the results of the Random Forest (RF) regression model and Support Vector Regression (SVR) model in predicting zinc (Zn) and lead (Pb) concentrations using space remote sensing compare to traditional methods in mapping geochemical elements in stream sediments in Central Wales?
Output:
The results of the Random Forest (RF) regression model and Support Vector Regression (SVR) model in predicting zinc (Zn) and lead (Pb) concentrations using space remote sensing show promising performance compared to traditional methods in mapping geochemical elements in stream sediments in Central Wales.

The study utilized satellite spectral reflectance data from Sentinel-2 with a spatial resolution of 10 m. The RF model achieved significant R2 values of 0.74 (p < 0.01) and 0.7 (p < 0.01) during training and testing for predicting Zn concentrations. Similarly, the SVR model achieved significant R2 values of 0.72 (p < 0.01) and 0.64 (p < 0.01) for training and testing in predicting Pb concentrations.

These results indicate that both the RF and SVR models have a high level of accuracy in predicting the concentrations of Zn and Pb in stream sediments using space remote sensing. The performance of these machine learning models outperforms other models used in the study, such as the Generalized Linear Model (GLM), Deep Neural Network (DNN), and Decision Tree (DT) regression models.
